Award.AwardTitle: Robust Design of Compliant DNA Origami Mechanisms

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
DNA origami mechanisms are nanometer scale mechanical devices that are made of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) biological materials. For comparison, a human hair is approximately 80,000 to 100,000 nanometers wide. Self-assembled via the so called DNA base-pairing process, the motion of these tiny mechanisms can be controlled to accomplish a task similar to machines and robots in the macro world. This technique has the potential to revolutionize medicine or reduce resource consumption and environmental pollution in manufacturing processes. For example, DNA nano-robots could potentially be used for nano-manufacturing, for molecular transport in bioreactors, for targeting cancer cells for drug delivery, or even for repairing damaged tissue. However, the motion of these nano-mechanisms is extremely difficult to control due to significant thermal fluctuation in solution, random errors in the molecular self-assembly process, and variation in material and structure properties. This award supports the fundamental research to address these challenges by developing a novel robust-design methodology borrowed from macroscopic compliant-mechanism design. The computational design tools resulting from this research will enable us to effectively design DNA nano-machines that are more accurately controllable, and that can be used in medicine for improving public health.

Recent success in applying kinematic mechanism principles in design of DNA origami nano-mechanisms has now opened new significant challenges in quantifying and managing the mechanical behavior of these mechanisms. The goal of this award is to develop a robust design framework for compliant DNA origami mechanisms to improve motion control and enable a wider range of mechanical behavior of DNA nano-structures. This design framework incorporates synthesis of commonly used compliant joints, pseudo-rigid-body models, kinetostatic analysis, synthesis algorithms and statistical theory based method for uncertainty quantification and management. The computational tools and experimental processes resulting from this research will enable: (a) design of DNA origami mechanisms with broader scope of mechanical behavior, (b) characterization of the properties of these nano-mechanisms, and (c) uncertainty quantification and management of DNA origami structures.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this award is to develop a robust design framework for compliant DNA origami mechanisms to improve motion control and enable a wider range of mechanical behavior of DNA nano-structures. In terms of intellectual merits, the research team have developed several computational design tools and theoretical models for compliant DNA origami mechanisms including pseudo-rigid-body models, kinetostatic analysis, uncertainty quantification. These design models and tools are very critical for predicting motion behavior of these device nanostructures and enable us to effectively design DNA nano-machines that are more accurately controllable. To demonstrate the effectiveness of these computational tools, we have designed, prototyped and analyzed several DNA origami mechanisms.  More specifically, we have extended the pseudo-rigid-body model theory from macroscopic compliant mechanisms to design of compliant DNA origami mechanisms. This theory has been successfully applied to analyze a compliant bistable four-bar mechanism and accurately predict the stiffness and energy landscape of the device. We have also designed a reconfigurable paper origami structure called ?water-bomb base? that can transform between various shapes upon actuation. Our computational model based on kinematic theory well agrees with the experimental data. Another important contribution of this award is a hybrid computational framework combining coarse-grained modeling with kinematic variance analysis for predicting the uncertainties in the motion path of a multi-component DNA origami mechanism. This framework includes coarse-grained modeling to evaluate the variation in geometry of individual components due to thermal fluctuations. Kinematic variance analysis is incorporated to predict the motion path uncertainty of the entire mechanism, which agreed well with experimental characterization of motion. This integration of computational analysis, modeling tools, and experimental methods establish a basis to predict and manage motion uncertainties of general DNA origami mechanisms.

In terms of broader impacts, the design models and tools developed in this award will significantly extend our ability to design dynamic DNA origami nano devices that serve as the key components used for nanorobots benefiting numerous applications such as precise drug delivery in medicine for improving public health. To disseminate the research outcomes to a broader society, the project team including graduate students and PIs have made significant efforts in organizing conference workshops, on-site or remote tutorials as well as presenting at international and national conferences and giving talks to many academic institutions. We have also made efforts to distribute the design tools to general public through online resources. Through supplemental support, at least four undergraduate research assistants have been supported to assist the research in this project.

 


Last Modified: 11/22/2019
Modified by: Hai-Jun Su

To demonstrate the effectiveness of these computational tools, we have designed, prototyped and analyzed several DNA origami mechanisms. This theory has been successfully applied to analyze a compliant bistable four-bar mechanism and accurately predict the stiffness and energy landscape of the device. Our computational model based on kinematic theory well agrees with the experimental data. In terms of broader impacts, the design models and tools developed in this award will significantly extend our ability to design dynamic DNA origami nano devices that serve as the key components used for nanorobots benefiting numerous applications such as precise drug delivery in medicine for improving public health.
